title: Xiaomi Yi ZMR250 dampened tilted mount

description.text:
This is a mount for ZMR250 quadcopter, to attach the popular Xiaomi Yi action camera. It handles vibration and also noise dampening.  
Use open cell foam for noise dampening pad. Sorbothane, and other vibration dampening materials such as 3M vibration dampening tape can be used between camera and quad, but the mount also works without them. The camera is ultimately held in place with velcro strip, that has maximum width of about 12mm.  
I used M3 cap head screws for the mount and also for mounting the quad's top plate, so holes are designed accordingly. The accessorynutholder parts go on the underside of top plate with some super glue, so mount can be removed quickly with just two screws.  
edit: Added new 25 and 40 degree tilted versions with ziptie holes in them, so these models allow either bolt or ziptie mounting.

comments.text: Thanks! I usually use about 20-25% honeycomb infill. On a small model like this, you can use lower infill if you use for example 3 perimeters. But when you use 2 perimeters, use higher infill like 25%. I also usually lower the limit when the slicing program starts making solid infill. Slic3r default is 70 mm^2 I think, and I usually use about 35 mm^2 setting.

author: lowrizzle

description.text:
This is a redesign of thing 4101. For a long time I was wondering why my z axis is wobbling although I centered it perfectly.
The answer was quite simple: My printing speed is set too high.
Due to this the whole mendel is shaking very much when it is printing small parts.
This causes a little shift in the z axis, which is only fixed at the bottom. The result is that layers do not fit perfectly in z direction. It is only about 1/20 mm but one can see it as relief on prints with a layer thickness of about 0.2 mm. So I searched and found thing 4101 which was exactly what I was looking for. Thanks a lot to hyperwerk! A little change in the design so that one can insert a 608 bearing and the wobbling of the z-axis is nearly eliminated. You can read more about it on: www.ifeelbeta.de greetings
BonsaiBrain
Print it, mount it to the top of the z-axis of your mendel without disassembling the whole z-axis.

comments.text: you could leave a 1mm gap in the 608 bearing by locking the top and bottom side with 2 nuts on each side, and space it by placing an Allen wrench in between, and remove it when the parts are tight, the locked bottom nuts then will not move for the washer and the gear, and the other nut and the final bolt. i did this and my modified Mendel does 500mm/min with 50% power on motor  in z axis. before it did only 20ms/min with full power on motor. this is great though it seems like it adds stability! :)
comments.author: jamesvilleneuve

comments.text: Possible Fix
comments.author: Radcnc

comments.text: I think the reason for this wobbling is, we have started to all use the new electronics, and taken the flat board off the front of the printer. The flat board clamped to the two front or back uprights gave the printer no wobble. Just my two cents worth.

title: Super X 125mm FPV racer conversion kit

description.text:
[RELEASED] V2.2 frame, Big change to compensate resonance in the frame, Needed 2XM2 screw [BETA] : For those with older SuperX frame (arm and plate in 1 piece)
i've made the V2.2 base frame with arms and screws. But untested feel free to give some returns.

After many weeks of testing, here the V1.2 Fpv racer printable kit to convert your super-X 125mm to a stunning fpv racer.
Great agility, and a lot of fun ! The frame had been designed for Fpv race, the flat bottom and shape let you make your turn without yawing, making the quad acting like a plane when getting speed. Compatible with stock lipo for 5 minutes race.
Also compatible with 350mah to 750mah nanotech ultra flat lipo pack.
The Camera pod is designed for the 1gr camera you can find here
http://fpvhobby.com/83-1-gram-nano-camera.html
or maybe many other place on the web.
Video TX is this one:
http://www.fpvhobby.com/229-new-mini-58-ghz-avtx-for-fatshark-.html
But compatible with any same form factor emiter. Since we are in 1S battery pack, you need a 5V step-up
you can find it anywhere on the web With the 350 nanotech batt, the complete quad is 63gr

Demo video : https://youtu.be/yXwBG_ORxpY
Another One : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=amVn4RQ_yHo
To Resume all part U need.
For the V1 Frame
-FPV-SX-Upper-Frame
-FPV-SX-Base-Frame
-FPV-SX-Cam-Pod
-FPV-SX-RollBar or FPV-SX-RollBar V2.2
This is the lighter set-up, only 52gr For the V2.2 Stronger but heavier
-FPV-SX-Upper-Frame V2.2
-FPV-SX-Base-Frame V2.2
-FPV-SX-Cam-Pod
-FPV-SX-RollBar or FPV-SX-RollBar V2.2
And New, the half moon feet !
This set up is heavier, 56gr but far more rigid BETA : For those with older SuperX frame (arm and plate in 1 piece)
i've made the V2.2 base frame with arms. But untested feel free to give some returns.

Why buy a dice tower when you can design your own!  
Dimensions are approximately 150 mm tall, 150 mm long, and 90 mm wide. The tower door opening is 40 mm wide. All the dice shown in the picture can be dropped in one handful and consistently stay in the dice tray. The assembly is approximately 220 grams with a 10% infill. I would guess that you could scale it down by 50% and still get a standard D6 through it, but I haven't tested it.   
It prints as two parts for ease of storage. The version 6 tower needs support (only for the hex fitting into the tray), but the tray does not. The tolerance between the two parts is loose.
UPDATE: Version 8 modifies the hex key/hole joint to eliminate the large amount of support needed on the tower around the hex. The tray has been enlarged to have a 7mm border around the tower and hex key/hole in the tray is now the size of the tower. Radial clearance was reduced to .5mm for a tighter fit. The wall thickness around the tower windows was also increased to improve the strength. I have not printed this version yet.

comments.text: Printed the larger one without support. Came out great!  Dice do seem to tumble out, but I'm going to glue a small piece of felt on the bottom ramp with the hopes it will rob them of just enough momentum to keep them in.  Thanks for the upload!

So after doing a print with this, my motor was extremely hot. Thanks for pointing this out. I could of damaged my motor and who knows what else.
comments.author: 3DWaves

comments.text: The main purpose of this is for proper spacing to attach the extruder motor to the heatblock. The heatsink does not touch the motor itself, there is a plastic spring loaded drive block in between it. Because of this, the heatsink doesn't get very warm.The M3 screw that attaches the motor to the heatblock is just barely short enough to thread onto the motor. That got stripped on mine so I made a thinner heatsink to enable the M3 screws to reach the threads that still grip on the motor.

author: dlg

description.text:
Print this kit and attach the parts 1/2 aluminum tubing for an awesome blowgun!! All of the parts were printed out of Ninjaflex. The mouth piece and the tip could be printed out of PLA or ABS.  The pellet holder and pellets should be printed out of Ninjaflex or similar material.  
The pellet design of the darts make it very fast and accurate. They work great with or without sharp tips.

The mouthpiece is pretty straight forward, just print it out of whatever material you like. I choose black Ninjaflex. The darts should be made out of Ninjaflex or another flexible material so the tail of the pellets can grip enough of the barrel to not fall out, but not so much that they are hard to blow. Getting a perfect fit is the tough part. My setup:
Flashforge Creator X
Ninjaflex - Lava color, so they are easy to find. I find that for my printer, the Ninjaflex needs to be set at about 1.35 extrusion rate, which is a bit higher than most other filaments. Bed temp: 40 deg C.
Extruder temp: 232 deg C.
3 Walls
30% Infill (I use 0% infill on the pellets)
30 mm/s print speed.
Build plate fan on Pellets scaled to 1.002% (This is the number to play with when adjusting the fit to the barrel.) I used nail gun finishing nails on some of mine. Just push them through the dart, from the bottom and super glue them in. They also fly great without the sharp tips. *Note: I can only get good prints by printing two pellets at a time. . The good news is that they only take about 20 mins to print. I just print them while I work. You can finish the tube by covering it with black or camo duct tape for a nice looking finish.

Drop in replacement spider coupling for Printrbot Simple Metal. My Simple Metal came with a flexible helical coupling for the Z axis that would stretch or compress during a print, making the Z axis very inaccurate, and causing uneven layers. After finding out that a flexible helical coupling on the Simple Metal is used for the wrong layout, as it should not have vertical load on the coupler, people recommended a spider coupling instead, as it can support vertical load while still allowing twist compression. This is that outcome - to test this theory I designed and 3D printed the coupling using PLA and the spider with NinjaFlex-SemiFlex to allow for flexibility.  
After installing the new coupling, new prints where coming out better than expected, Z axis based walls were smooth to the touch unlike with the helical coupling. Well worth the time and effort of upgrading the Simple Metal.

Print bottom and top couplers at 100% infill using rigid filament (i.e. PLA)  
Print spider at 20% infill using flexiable filament (i.e. NinjaFlex-SemiFlex)

title: Alien Z Probe  auto deploy and retract

description.text: An auto bed levelling probe with significantly greater accuracy than a conventional microswitched probe.  The probe incorporates an auto deploy and retract mechanism which is springless, decreasing the effector load.  We have repeatedly taken sub 50micron readings using this probe.

Requires:
1 x 175mm by 1.5mm Tig Welder Electrode (any type will do)http://www.rapidwelding.com/dynamic/DisplayItem.aspx?c=ThoriatedTungsten&zl=1
1 x 1.6mm CK Standard 3 Series Collet Body http://www.rapidwelding.com/dynamic/DisplayItem.aspx?c=CK-3CB116&zl=3
1 x 1.6mm CK Standard Collet. 3 Series http://www.rapidwelding.com/dynamic/DisplayItem.aspx?c=CK-3C116&zl=3
1x 10mm od, 4.3mm id washer or similer, 1mm thick. (Mine is a Meccano One)
1 x Small Neodymium Magnet
1 x 3mm x 12mm Caphead
1 x 2.5mm x 12mm Caphead
1x 3mm x 80mm Rod (I used Meccano again)
2 x Thin Wires
1 x Set of Printed Parts Refer to youtube video for Assembly
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SWFJIXH6jFM Also a video of it in use
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DuBtdkLYIj0
Just remember to glue a little magnet to the top of the rotating arm (top deploy arm) and half a small washer to the top left side of the Terminal Contactor Plug.
The welder rod will need snapping off at the correct length for your printer, the Kossel Mini required 20mm removing.
The 1.6mm CK standard collet may need the ends adjusting so the rod slides freely. The collet can be moved up and down in the collet body to adjust the probe for your printer. Setup: (For Kossel Mini) Set in Configuration.h
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET (0, 24.0, -2.08, 0) Set in Marlin_main.cpp
void deploy_z_probe() {
feedrate = homing_feedrate[X_AXIS];
destination[X_AXIS] = 0; // T3P3 Kossel Mini R2
destination[Y_AXIS] = 67; // T3P3 Kossel Mini R2
destination[Z_AXIS] = 22;
prepare_move_raw(); feedrate = homing_feedrate[X_AXIS]/10;
destination[X_AXIS] = -23; // T3P3 Kossel Mini
prepare_move_raw();
st_synchronize();
} void retract_z_probe() {
feedrate = homing_feedrate[Z_AXIS];
destination[Z_AXIS] = current_position[Z_AXIS] + 40; // T3P3 Kossel Mini R2
prepare_move_raw(); destination[X_AXIS] = -40;
destination[Y_AXIS] = 60 ;
destination[Z_AXIS] = 40;
prepare_move_raw(); // Move the nozzle below the print surface to push the probe up.
feedrate = homing_feedrate[Z_AXIS]/10;
destination[Z_AXIS] = current_position[Z_AXIS] - 35;
prepare_move_raw(); feedrate = homing_feedrate[Z_AXIS];
destination[Z_AXIS] = current_position[Z_AXIS] + 30;
prepare_move_raw();
st_synchronize();

OpenSCAD pentagonal hexecontahedron tile with holes for magnets.

This is a single tile for a pentagonal hexecontahedron.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentagonal_hexecontahedron You'll need a total of 60 tiles, and 4 disc magnets per tile (axially magnetized). That's 240 magnets in total. I bought mine on eBay in bulk and used gel-type superglue to secure them in the tiles. Magnet orientation:
The two long sides with magnets must have opposite polarities facing out.
The two short sides with magnets must have opposite polarities facing out.
The last short side has no magnet hole.
All the tiles have to be identical with regard to the magnet alignment. A good way to keep track is to make your first tile according to the rules above, and use it as a references for every subsequent tile (test your magnets against it). See the User Defined Variables section for the parameters you may want to change (magnet holes and overall size of tile, total 4 parameters). I printed mine with the ReplicatorG accelerated defaults and no raft or support. They printed in about 20 minutes each.
I painted 1/3 of the tiles (20 tiles) in gold liquid leaf paint. The rest are left plain (black ABS). The STL was generated with the long side as 4 cm and the tile thickness 1 cm. See also my pentagonal icositetrahedron magnetic tile @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820309 Or on github: https://github.com/eshira/polyhedra

author: jonnyboy323

description.text: OpenSCAD pentagonal icositetrahedron tile with holes for magnets.

This is a single tile for a pentagonal icositetrahedron.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentagonal_icositetrahedron You'll need a total of 24 tiles, and 4 disc magnets per tile (axially magnetized). That's 96 magnets in total. I bought mine on eBay in bulk and used gel-type superglue to secure them in the tiles. Magnet orientation:
The two long sides with magnets must have opposite polarities facing out.
The two short sides with magnets must have opposite polarities facing out.
The last short side has no magnet hole.
All the tiles have to be identical with regard to the magnet alignment. A good way to keep track is to make your first tile according to the rules above, and use it as a references for every subsequent tile (test your magnets against it). See the User Defined Variables section for the parameters you may want to change (magnet holes and overall size of tile, total 4 parameters). I printed mine with the ReplicatorG accelerated defaults and no raft or support. They printed in about 20 minutes each. The STL was generated with the long side as 4 cm and the tile thickness 1 cm. See also my pentagonal hexecontahedron magnetic tile @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820294 Or on github: https://github.com/eshira/polyhedra

title: More robust marble machine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Slight modification to Tulio Laanens fantastic Marblemachine #2.
Combining the lift and the turning blade removes a brittle connection and gives 1 less part to worry about. It also allows the lift much better bed adhesion by coupling it to the large turning blade.
The hole in the cap has been enlarged allowing you to drop the screw/blade assy right in.

comments.text: nice! When I red what you wanted to change I thought that you wanted to connect the tree separate lift parts to one for some reason. But nicely done. It seems that more people had problems while printing the little triangular part, so I think this is a great solution.
comments.author: Tulio

comments.text:
It really helps the screw stick to the bed too.
My print was 2 hours due to printing only the new screw and cap. I had to keep printspeed slower than I want to make sure each layer had enough time to cool.
Printed in PLA at 195c temperature with 14s per layer and a huge fan blowing on it. Any higher temp, faster print or less fan and it would become uneven in the screw overhang facing away from the fan.
comments.author: Tulio

comments.text:
Yes I see, I have to say I think its indeed a asset that the screw sticks to the bed better. Great tip!
And by the way, I'm alway surprised when I hear what temperature people print with. At my school and at my town's Fablabb, we print almost always around 228c with PLA and mostly on 40mm/s. that always gives me the best results (like my marble machine in the video), Its quite interesting how varying the setting are.
comments.author: KreAture

comments.text:
I had to reduce my temp from my normal 220c when reprinting only the cap and screw since the first screw came loose while printing the main track. Normally I print at 80-100mm/s but depending on complexity and size, (and patience), i go as high as 140.
I will be printing a scaled down version for 7mm spheres soon as I have a bag of those.

description.text:
Modification to the Mendel90 y-idler-bracket to tension the belt as it is done up More at
http://empoweredplastic.blogspot.com.au/2013/04/todays-result-modified-mendel90-y-idler.html
  • Added T5 belt version
Mount this to the luggage rack on a bicycle, slide a pole in and head off to you favorite fishing hole. Fits a 16mm rail. Version 2 works on some rear forks about 5 degreesish off vertical.

I used 6/32 screws and nuts.  The nuts didn't fit in the recesses but a pair of needle nose pliers did the job.  If it tries to turn on you I added a hole at the base for a support rod or line the clamp with a couple pieces of electrical tape and it shouldn't move.

This model's inspiration came from a YouTube video; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4tHmGSwrgxA I reinforced the motor mount since the one he used was made out of metal, so this model was made thicker with long cylinders that go through it to also help reinforce the model. The model to my testing at only 75% infill gave results that more than adequate for this purpose, but 100% infill would be the best. To attach this mount to the longboard I would recommend just using a 2 part epoxy that is safe with the plastic you are using.

The belt I used was this one from Royal Supply here in the states: http://www.royalsupply.com/store/pc/Gates-320-5M-15-PowerGrip-HTD-Belt-9293-2707-1039p18317.htm Printing; Recommended material:ABS
Infill:100%
Layer height: 0.3mm/300 microns or lower layer height
Speed: 25mm/s I printed this on a Zortrax M200 btw.

title: Remix of the Adafruit "Light Ring" module includes mounting hole/post bits.

description.text:
This is a remix of the Adafruit "Light Ring" model used on the Camera Light Ring.
I wanted positive mounting posts to more securely seat the diffuser ring over top of the diffuser that holds the NeoPixel ring, so I made this. In test-prints it fit together pretty well, but as always, YMMV, esp. when printing w/ PLA. Enjoy!

Downloaded the Adafruit 24-pixel Lightring model, imported it into OpenSCAD and went to town. Both halves are from the "neoring-cover.stl" file, one is scaled up by 1.5 in Z. The socket/pin are simple OpenSCAD cylinder union/difference ops.

https://learn.adafruit.com/really-simple-animatronic-tail https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qn27Ye0vWRQ Animatronics is tricky. It requires mechanical engineering in addition to the software and electrical engineering of most of our projects. Normally when I talk with cosplayers just getting started with electronics, I point them toward a light or sound project, to limit the number of variables. This project reduces animatronics to its simplest case. Mechanical tails are complex stuff, often involving armatures for bones and cable mechanisms to simulate muscles and tendons. Rather that fighting against gravity, we’ll instead make it our ally. Thinking of the tail as a pendulum, a single small servo and a little math is all it takes.

author: edblagg

description.text:
This is a case for a CMUcam5 (Pixy) It is an object tracking camera!
http://www.cmucam.org/projects/cmucam5 The bottom of the case has GoPro-like lugs so this case should just swap into whatever GoPro holding accessory you might have. The application this case was designed for only required that the mini-USB in the back be accessible, so the other connections are sealed off once the back is screwed on. This case was designed so that the push button is accessible, the indicator LED is view-able and the lens cap can be added or removed. Prints like a dream.

There are three case options.  
Pixy Case.stl is the design I actually used for my project.  The lugs on the case are 0.2" longer than your standard GoPro mount.  I needed this to accommodate a wing nut.  
Pixy Case_Spec Clevis.stl - more closely emulates a GoPro mount.  
Pixy Case_Spec Clevis_Support Feature.stl - has a support feature under the lug to help with printing.  Some printer/fillament/setting combinations won't need this feature, others might.
A remix of DDeGonge888's 3uP Fan Bracket to adapt it to the direct mount SeeMeCNC EZStruder. Requires the original fan duct Fan_Bracket_B.stl to complete.

In addition to this part, also print DDeGonge888's Fan_Bracket_B.stl. Because of the thin wall thickness, and severely sloping sides, I recommend printing the duct as slowly as possible to prevent gaps forming in the walls of the duct. I printed at 20mm/s, faster speeds was putting gaps in the duct walls. To complete assembly you will also need: 4 x M3*20mm Button Head Hex Socket Cap Screws
5 x M3 Hex Nuts
1 x 40mm Silent Fan [e.g. Scythe Mini KAZE 40mm Silent Case Fan (SY124010L)]
1 x M3*40mm Button Head Hex Socket Cap Screw
1 x M3*10Φ5 Knurled Nut
6 x M3 Washers
1 x M3 Hand Thumbscrew Attach the fan guard and duct to the fan using the button head M3*20mm screws, washers and nuts. Observe the correct fan direction (usually marked on the side of the fan body) so that the fan is blowing towards the workpiece. Run the button head M3*40mm bolt from the back of the EZStruder, then secure with the knurled nut and tighten. Then add washer, fan bracket, washer, and thumbscrew and tighten hand-tight. Ensure the bottom of the duct does not drag against the work surface, and also does not contact the hot-end. Wire the fan as appropriate for your application. In my case, this fan was wired to the Printrboard's fan header so that the slicer can control the fan speed.

title: Holocron Lighted
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
First off....Credit to Hambone211 as i used his face design, but nothing else. This is my first creation. I've spent a few weeks on it off an on. Getting dimensions right, changing the design and making it fit better. I use Autodesk 123Design to create it. The key Items that must be purchased are pictured. Radio shack on/off switch $3-4
LED Bulb is a kit from AutoZone for 12volt applications. $15 Alternatively; If you want to just buy the LED bulbs they can be bought on ebay. I ordered 2 for $3 with shipping. I was just impatient and saw this kit in the store. I used the supplied battery pack in the packaging that allows you to test the light while sealed. Inside the pack it uses 10 AG13LR44 battery. Very cheap in bulk on ebay. I also included a base design for a 9volt battery. The 9v battery works and will likely last longer, but is not as bright as it is lower voltage. Also included is an LED mount if you buy just the bulbs on ebay. The "kit" comes with a housing the bulb goes into, so this one will just take the bulb itself. You can solder the wires directly to the bulb. The faces have guides on them to assure proper fit (upgraded design from Hambone's flat edges) Print 1x "Top" , 2x "Side 1" , 2x "Side 2" The faces are beveled to accommodate 2mm plexiglassacrylic. I found some scraps at local plastics shop (Tap Plastics) Choose your color or style to put in them. All that is required is a little soldering of the wires. The entire project has been printed completely and works great as seen in the pic. The battery box should be printed upside with support. The Base should also be printed upside down (for battery door recess to print correctly) but no support needed as edges are 45degrees. 12hour total print time
44300mm filament used (calculated by "3d Printer Calculator")
Total filament est cost $3.60 @ $27 per kg roll. UPDATE: My build plate is 200x200. The original size would only allow one face to print at a time. So i made it smaller ( 90mm wide) so more can fit. The Smaller Holocron file is also only set up for 9volt battery and just the bulb (no kit needed). To make it easy, faster and cheaper to make.

author: Badkitty

title: Transmitter module case for Turnigy 9X - to fit FrSky DHT module

description.text:
This is a replacement transmitter module case for the Hobby King Turnigy 9x. If you want to upgrade the unit to the FrSky DHT radio module, there are several ways to install it inside the transmitter. But I decided to install it in the same location and so needed a new case.   
I located the antenna in the regular position, so it still needs to run down and through a hole to the module. An antenna mount is included with this design. It is designed to be a tight press fit onto the existing stem. The bind button and LED is mounted on the back lid, and the connection to the transmitter pins is by means of a header connector. The board is just poster taped to the back of the box. I did not use the toggle switch as I only use the D-mode of the transmitter, so it is not even installed.  Telemetery will be run out the back via the same hole.  
You should only need supports under the wing tabs, and under the antenna adapter.

This is a foot to fit M10 threaded rod for a baby gate.  
We have a new Springer Spaniel puppy on the way, so I dug out the old baby gate (to keep her safe from our other rather boisterous Springer) only to find that the feet were all missing. So I designed this as a replacement.  
I have used the functions.scad file from Josef Prusa to model the nut in scad. You don't need it but it is included just incase you want to see the nut rendered in scad.  
The model scad itself is pretty simple and is parametric.
Print as many as you need - fit some theaded rod and adjusting nuts and you are good to go!

description.text:
Update 5/12/2015: Did some bashing with the Traxxas Stampede and had a breakage at the front A-Arm mount. Re-printed in new direction and so far no breakages. Im sure it was because of the direction i printed it in. I highly recommend printing in the direction I created the .STL file in. Had to re-size and move alot of the holes to make a model that would bolt in a stock piece location and work. Front A-Arms rubbed on the plastic in the original model and fixed that. Alot of holes were to small on original model and would snap when forcing bolt in :). Now you should be able to print and have a working piece straight from the printer. Setup: Hacked Davinci with repetier firmware loaded and RepetierHost
Stock .4 nozzle and .4 layer width
Use an 1/8 inch drill bit to get the holes for the Front A-Arm screws perfect and there wont be any play at all. Any fitment issues and acetone will help for small clearances that are to tight.

title: Deltaprintr fan shrouds for material and print head.

description.text: These are two fan shrouds for the Deltaprintr. Both can be used at the same time. These clip onto the traxxas joints and are designed for standard 40mm fans. I've also included a fun fan shield. The print head shroud was based on this one by Ruyck. To design this, I took a bunch of measurements using a caliper and drew these designs up. Simple as that. Well, I did draw inspiration from Ruyck's design.

When assembling this, I suggest that you loosen one of the screws holding the taxxas joints in place. This will allow the shrouds to snap on without breaking a clip. Obviously, don't forget to tighten the screw back up.  
I used a tap to make sure that the screw holes were sized properly  in the shrouds and to make sure the screws had something to screw into.  From there I just used some 10mm M3 screws to hold everything in place.

title: GEEETech MK8 Printhead Fan Shroud (compact) ver 2.0 w/ LED mounts

description.text:
Same as my first version except with the addition of 4 LED mounts to add light up under the printhead:  
This is a compact print cooling shroud built for the GEEETech MK8 Extruder/Printhead - for me it's on an Acrylic Prusa i3b. The shroud wraps around the aluminum cooling heatsink which on my printer has the cooling fins in a vertical orientation. I used SketchUp to design the simple surround and ducting to direct air out of the bottom of the fan/heatsink and down to the front and back of the printhead for cooling the print quite well. I added a thicker 20mm 40x40 fan for more airflow/pressure and sealed it using aluminum tape (find at a Home Store, used for A/C ducting).  
Result: airflow is actually surprisingly good and directed exactly on print extrusion area . . . and I don't need a "flying fan" attachment.  
Ver 2.0 adds the LED's x4 directing light around the nozzle so I don't need to find a flashlight every time I want to see how my print is doing or to inspect/clean my nozzle.

Designed in SketchUp
Mesh corrected using netfabb
Printcontrol with Repetier host LED's I used are: BCMD204UWC (3200mcd, 3mm, 3.2Vf @20mA - 25Viewing Angle) actual measurements are 3.1mm diam with a 3.8mm diam lip at the very top x 6.3mm in length, 3.3v, set in the mounts with silicone at the top of each bulb, hooked up in series then directly to the 12v power supply with a separate on/off switch (see my other things for the switch box),

comments.text:
Nice design. I made one for my printer, and noticed that the duct closest to the front seems to be blocked. The rear one is open, but has some weird geometry inside. Still learning Sketchup, or I'd try to fix it myself. Meanwhile, I'm cranking up my Dremel tool.
Thanks for a 'cool' mod for my printer!

comments.text: I love the LEDs I was thinking of the same thing.  Is your print head mount stock?  I just got my i3b a week ago and my mount is a printed part.  I bring that up because the aluminium plate that mounts between my print head and the plastic mount bracket covers the bottom of heat sink so air only exits through the top.
comments.author: docbrew

comments.text: No it is not stock, The stock GEEETech Prusa Acrylic i3b extruder mount (the PLA printed ring) can melt/warp with an extended print (see their own Geeetech forum for multiple customers who have had this complaint), and the aluminum GEEETech mounting plate was too wide and got in the way for this cooler/blower idea, so I rebuilt my extruder mount from Aluminum L-channel.

This is an idea that have been on my mind for quite a long time but never had the time to execute it until now.  
When I assembled my Sunhokey Prusa I3 3D printer kit, I attached the timing belt to the X-carriage using cable tie as per instruction.  As effective as it is, to me the cable tie looks kinda nasty and primitive.  That's when I thought a kind of sleeve or ring can be used to clip the belt as a replacement to the cable tie.  
It sounded so simple and insignificant but oh well I have a 3D printer anyway so I might as well give it a try.  
And so I designed and printed the attached OBJ file and voila!... it works!  Now it is easy to clip the belt... easy to remove the clip and put it back (no need to cut the cable tie and put a new one if adjustment needs to be done)... and it is more PROFESSIONAL-LOOKING now.  
I liked it a lot.  
Hope you find this useful too.  
Keep printing everyone... cheers!

The model is designed to print in one piece then the joints broken loose with what should be just little blobs of plastic. It is a real test of the calibration, cleanness and precision of your 3D printer. I had to take it apart to print the parts, still showing some blobbiness from my system. The all in one model is from moving the parts back into place and may not be totally precise, check before printing. Also found the normals were flipped plus multiple parts had multiple walls, both can bomb slicers. Flipped the normals and ran them through netfabb, the files are half the size. Jazmy is really on to something with these ball joints, very cool. Nice modeling also.

These are some simple clips to help with the routing of the wires on your Lulzbot TAZ or other 3D printers constructed with 20mm 8020 extrusion. These clips replace the ghetto looking zip ties. on the frame, for routing the wiring harnesses. They insert with just a 90 degree twist, hold the harness securely, and allow you to easily detach and reattach the harness for maintenance. Included are a versions which slide on from the end, and versions that insert with a 90 degree twist. Both work well. These harness clips were part of a project to clean up the TAZ's profile in preparation for adding an enclosure. Details to follow. Blue skies,
Jim Rasmussen
TabSynth Design Works

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

We printed it a 0.27.

Infill:

98 Percent infill, two shells

Notes: A version of this clip with a zip tie is in thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1035974

Printed with 100% fill and Zero extra shells.  Installs with a twist, holds your cable guides securely.  Print it in ABS for flexibility.  This part is an SCAD extrusion of a profile in dxf format.  Feel free to go in and modify the profile to make different clip geometries.  You can also modify the fit for different extrusions.  This is a tight fit on the Mitsumi extrusion used by Lulzbot for their TAZ printer.  Easy to modify, so have at it.

title: DYS Eagle eye gimbal CAMLEVER mod

description.text:
I think that this gimbal has a great design, but adjusting the center of gravity is a pain, you have to tight and untight screws constantly. I decided to make my own CAMLEVERS, so just moving the lever, you get the axis free to move to the desired position. You will need:
4 CamLeverShort for the camera cage.
4 6mm diameter aluminum bar with 3mm holes
8 M3x20 screws 4 CamLever or CamLeverLong (for the other axis)
4 6mm diameter aluminum bar with 3mm holes
8 M3x45 or M3x50 screws If you use the CamLever, you have a gap between the screws and the lever, so the lever moves and is not centered unless you center it before adjust.
If you don't want to have this gap, use CamLeverLong.

remixed_from.title: Wood reel and reel plastic support for SmartrapCore 3D printer box

description.text:
This is a simple spool support for the smartrapcore.
It work for small spool (tested for up to 750gr but I think it'll work for 1kg). Just hang on the top of teh smarrapcore. I hanged mine on the right side of it (as I have my extruder outside) and I use a small clip to guide the filament. Picture of the setup to follow. All improvement are welcome.

title: Customizable Wrench with Nut holding Cap

description.text:
It can be really tricky to screw something together when you don't have enough space to hold the nut with your finger in position. So I added support for a cap on the closed side of the wrench which can be used to hold a nut in position while screwing. This wrench is a derivate of gr0bs customizable wrench (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:47842). Also includes some minor enhancements:
  • deeper engraving
  • kerf size tightened
  • lowered text height

comments.text:
It's the Inmoov robot see site
http://inmoov.fr/
I make all of the bolts and nuts for the arms and head so they work well with the printed parts

description.text:
Shower head for the bathroom at work. This is not perfect but better than previously.  
hole=2mm

Printed on reprap i3 rework. 0.2 layer  
I don't have waterproof seal so I use hot glue. Screwed with a washer.

This housing ism meant for Red Pitaya board. v1.0 and v1.1 fit in this housing. There is a ventilation grills which enable airflow. Active ventilation is meant to be used together with this housing.
Housing enables easy access to fast analog SMA connectors.
Printing with 0.3 nozzle returns optimal results and easy installation of Red Pitaya board with no or minimal modifications. I've tested the heat dissipation with the closed version of the lid at room temperature. Red Pitaya survived but i don't recommend trying this. My Red Pitaya runs with this housing non-stop and there have not been any difficulties yet. Remove plasitc legs of Red Pitaya before inserting it into the housing! Fan used for this housing is 40x40x10 mm, 5V. The fan connects so the pins for the fan (5V) on Red Pitaya. I am not responsible for any damage the housing will cause. You are using and modifying it at your own risk. Thanks to LBM for leting me use the printer.

Using official documentation for Red Pitaya boards, i created the Red Pitaya model and used it to create this housing. I have made about 10 versions before this one because i wanted that Red Pitaya slides easily into the bottom housing.
Remove plasitc legs of Red Pitaya before inserting it into the housing!

The following system is designed to create a module for growing hydroponics home of small vegetables. It also has the ability to germinate the seeds of your plant. If you need to cultivate plants with special features not hesitate to change the design or the characteristics of the system Arduino and send them to us. Share your changes with us. Please also share the results of your cultivation.
Have fun!

Before starting the construction of your hydroponic system you choose plants that you are going to grow. In fact, for each type of vegetation will need to choose the amount and type of nutrients to dissolve in water, the type of LED to be purchased for the production of particular frequencies of light, the optimum PH water. Consider also that some types of vegetation can be planted together with other benefit because of some properties that exchange with the water circulating in the hydroponic system. Some vegetation types are not recommended instead together because they need different characteristics of nourishment

title: Light Chisel: A 6 degree of freedom input device for your computer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Light Chisel is a novel 6 degree of freedom input device for your computer. The Light Chisel could be tracked absolutely by two low cost VGA color cameras. More to the Light Chisel could be found on the project web: http://dcgi.felk.cvut.cz/projects/lightchisel/ This work has been presented at the Eurographics 2015 conference and the paper was published in the Computer Graphics Forum, Volume 34 (2015), 34-Issue 2:
http://diglib.eg.org/handle/10.1111/cgf12563 You may find the following video on the Light Chisel tracking interesting:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SFV0Sr1v2JM You may need to repackage the PlayStation 3 Eye cameras for the tracking purposes:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820888
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820866

The Light Chisel body is printed with a black PLA filament, the diffuse cylinder is printed with a natural PLA filament. We exchange the filament spools at the height Z=121mm. There are two RGB LEDs countersunk into the diffuse cylinder. The top is powered by a ribbon cable. The ribbon cable has to be carefully positioned into the flute of the diffuse cylinder. To increase homogenity of the light diffusion, we recommend to sand the diffuse cylinder. The main openscad file is the handle.scad
By default it will generate three Light Chisel bodies in a row. We print three devices at once because of the filament change from a black to a natural PLA. It takes time for the black pigment to fully clean out of the nozzle. By printing the three Light Chisels at once, the black pigment residuals get spread into one third of the layers. The electronics lid is generated by the opening_lid() macro of the handle.scad file. The battery door STL is generated by the battery_door.scad file. You will find the schematic, the printed circuit board design and the attiny13 controller firmware at our project site:
http://dcgi.felk.cvut.cz/projects/lightchisel/

remixed_from.author: slipshine
remixed_from.title: Galaxy S3 Phone Case - Fixed for Better Rep Rap Printing

description.text:
This is a case for Samsungs Galaxy S3.
It is modified (original design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:99363).
I printed this both in classic PLA and Laywood.
Fits perfectly when printed with my MBot Cube.
I will upload some pictures soon.

Printed with 0.1mm layer height and 20% infill without support.
Laywood didn't need raft, PLA did.

This is a remix of OPLink Case (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:351851). I wanted a method for securing the OPLink modem to my notebook so that they remain together as I'm moving around. This model clips easily to a MacBook Pro. Some very thin parts in this model as it was designed to be printed in Nylon with 100% infill so that there is flexibility in the clips that mount on the screen and the clips that join the two halves.

This is a lightsaber I made from scratch in Tinkercad. The concept is not mine, i got it from a lightsaber on Ultrasabers.com. Here is the link... http://www.ultrasabers.com/product-p/stunt-azurereaper.htm

This is a simple and adjustable diffuser for LED flashlights. It comes handy when the flashlight has too narrow beam and much wider or softer light is needed. The flashlight with the diffuser can be for example hung from the tree branch or from the top of the tent to illuminate wider area. The default dimensions are set up for the Zhishunjia ZSJ-T29 flashlight from DX.com: http://www.dx.com/p/zhishunjia-zsj-t29-cree-xm-l-t6-1000lm-5-mode-white-flashlight-black-1-x-18650-317226 (Note however: I cannot really recommend this particular flashlight - it is stated to have 2.4A circuitry and 1000 lumens, but in fact it gives only about 600 mA to the LED, which corresponds to about 250 lumens for Cree XM-L T6. Other than that, it is well built and works OK.) See also my other diffuser for the LZZ-186 headlamp, which is a bit more complicated: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:187055

Print it using a white material, of course :-)  
The best way is to download the OpenSCAD source, and adjust the parameters near the top of the file to fit your needs. The provided .stl file is for the ZSJ-T29 flashlight.  
The main parameter to be adjusted is ring_d - the diameter of the flashlight head. Add some more space around it (I have added 1.0 mm).   
Then it is necessary to set clip_h - the height of the clips above the print platform. The particular value depends on where excatly does your flashlight have narrower place for clips to hold on.  
The diaphragm parameter describes the thickness of the diaphragm - thicker means less light coming through, thinner means the danger of not very solid diaphragm. I used 0.5 mm, which is exactly two print layers (I use 0.25mm layer height).  
The other parameters can be left intact, or adjusted when really needed.

title: Box with a stand for a PS3 Eye camera to be used for infrared tracking

description.text:
We developed a box with a stand to repackage the PlayStation 3 Eye camera for infrared tracking purposes. The front side of the box features multiple holes for 5mm IR LEDs and the holes are slightly tilted to increase the illuminated area. The box is equipped with a pocket for an USB-B socket and for a 5mm barrel connector socket to power the IR illumination. We use the IR cameras to track a head position and a position of a half transparent mirror in a seated augmented reality setup. For more details on our Light Chisel project, see the project site:
http://dcgi.felk.cvut.cz/projects/lightchisel/ You may as well print the Light Chisel on your printer:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820765 You may need to print replacement boxes for the PS3 Eye cameras for the tracking purposes:
You may as well print the Light Chisel on your printer:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820765 You may need to build a pair of infrared cameras for head tracking:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820888

Each of the camera boxes is equipped with 12 IR LEDs. We use the LD 271 IR LEDs by OSRAM. We connected the LEDs into 4 serial chains and we picked a series resistor for each of the LED chains to draw a current of 40 mA. We built an add-on regulator board into a PC to deliver 9V/1A from a 12V Molex connector. Then each of the two LED chains consisting of 5 LEDs in series requires a series resistor of 68 Ohm, each of the two LED chains consisting of 6 LEDs in series requires a series resistor of 33 Ohm to draw around 40mA per single LED.  
Be careful to not overheat the LEDs. The datasheet of the LD 271 LED allows a maximum of 100 mA DC current per LED, but another graph shows current derating with increasing temperature. The LEDs will not withstand continuous 100mA current and one of our boxes printed from PLA actually melted under such a high temperature load. With the 40mA continuous current per LED the temperature at the LED leads rises to around 45 degrees of Celsius, which is OK.  
The electronics board is held inside the box by the original screws and by two additional M3 screws. The box is screwed to the holder by additional 4 M3 screws.

title: Robox iPhone 6+ bumper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Its no surprise that we love technology here at CEL UK, and the only thing we love more is integrating 3D printing into our gadgets. This Robox designed Phone 6+ bumper fits comfortably around your phone and is fastened with 1 M2.5 x 6 bolt to help you easily fit and remove it from your phone. The black print is printed using Colorfabbs XT-CF20 carbon fiber filament for durability. The white print is Glow in the Dark PLA, making it extremely easy to find in the dark. The orange print is CEL Highway orange ABS. Ensure your printer is well calibrated, print a known size block and measure it, adjust your 'step per unit' on both X and Y so that the block prints to the correct size. Find out more about the CEL Robox here; http://www.cel-robox.com/

title: Box with a stand for a PS3 Eye camera to be used for Light Chisel tracking

description.text:
We developed a box with a stand to repackage the PlayStation 3 Eye camera for the tracking purposes in a seated augmented reality setup. The box is equipped with a pocket for an USB-B socket and with two holes for RCA sockets for the camera shutter synchronization. We use two PS3 eye cameras to track our Light Chisel 6 degrees of freedom interaction tool in a seated augmented reality setup. For more details on our Light Chisel project, see the project site:
http://dcgi.felk.cvut.cz/projects/lightchisel/ You may as well print the Light Chisel on your printer:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820765 You may need to build a pair of infrared cameras for head tracking:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820866

The electronics board is held inside the box by the original screws and by two additional M3 screws. The box is screwed to the holder by additional 4 M3 screws. The PS3 Eye cameras may be modified for synchronization. You need to access the VSYNC and FSIN pins. You will find more details on the following two web pages: http://nuigroup.com/forums/viewthread/12445/ Step 9 - modifying the PS3 eye camera:
http://www.instructables.com/id/The-EyeWriter-20 To not break the printed board, we usually epoxy a piece of a blank copper clad board onto the PS3 printed board at the spot where there are no components and we use these newly added pieces as soldering points for the synchronization cables going to the RCA connectors. We then connect these soldering points to the vias on the PS3 board using a thin magnet wire. We then put a dab of the epoxy onto the soldered vias to avoid damage of the PS3 board by caused by tearing the soldering point out of the PS3 board. To avoid a damage of the camera circuit, we added a protection circuit USB6B1 from ST micro onto the camera synchronization lines:
http://www.st.com/st-web-ui/static/active/en/resource/technical/document/datasheet/CD00001361.pdf We also recommend to put clamp on ferrite beads on both ends of the camera synchronization cable.

OpenSCAD sourcecode coming soon.
Please note that this is an four tone instrument not a signalling device. Instead of blowing in with full force you should find the correct amount of air for each tone.

Several of these whistles where printed on the
Linuxwochen event (2015 in Vienna Austria)
http://www.linuxwochen.at/wien/

This whistle design is based on some accumulated experience.
  • The blade is sharper due to the horizontal printing orientation.
    In this orientation the blade has to have a blunter angle but this doesn't seem to matter at all.
  • The resonance chamber is airtight even with sub-optimal printer settings since all inner walls are 45° tilted ad thus no potentially porous top surfaces or bridged bottom surfaces are accessible to airflow.
  • Text with veeery high detail is possible since it is put on 45° inward slanted walls.
    • The gemstone shape naturally emerged due to the design restrictions.

I found that sound quality (lack of airiness) strongly depends on the used filament. (I used 0.1mm layer height and 30% infill)  
Btw: FDM ... fused deposition modelling - if you didn't know yet
